CatDescriptText: Ruth Simms, housewife, Mt. Washington and Donald Brown, truck driver, St. Clair Village, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, October 28, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., should come to Pittsburgh and take over the pastorate of a church, or should he remain in the South and continue his crusade?" Mrs. Simms' answer reads: "I think he should stay South and crusade, because those people need more help than we do."  Mr. Brown's answer reads: "He should come here, because he would do as well here as in the South."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Ruth Simms wearing coat with wide collar and dark top with two decorative squares at neckline, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Donald Brown wearing trench coat, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
